title: ENG09_pt 1: 3.3 Choosing Types of Evidence | SVHS

mainContent.text:
3.3 Choosing Types of Evidence

        Completion requirements
        



Evidence, the meat of the sandwich
So, if claims are the building blocks of all academic writing, and reasoning is the glue that keeps them together, then evidence is the actual building that takes shape. Evidence is the wooden structure that supports and is supported by all claims
    (building blocks). A better analogy might be that of the sandwich: claims are the bread (starters); reasoning are the condiments (the special sauce); and evidence is the main ingredient, the meat or the cheese, in the middle.  
Think of a paragraph as a sandwich. The C-E-C method illustrates this sandwich-making process:
C-E-C Paragraph:Claim: topic sentence and reasoning (1-2 sentences)  Evidence: quotes or data used as support (1-2 sentences) Commentary: analyzes the evidence and connects it to the claim. (2-4 sentences)



Evidence comes in all shapes and sizes. In English, teachers mainly require quotes from the text as evidence. In Social Studies, teachers may use artifacts (objects, maps, graphs). In science and math, data    is primarily used as evidence. A mix of all evidence may be presented in longer research projects.
In humanities, evidence is measured on how close it is to the original source. An original source is also known as a primary source. If someone paraphrases a primary source, it becomes a secondary source. If someone paraphrases a secondary source, it becomes a tertiary source. And so on...
For example: 

    
        I conduct an experiment on water quality and publish my results: PRIMARY SOURCE
        My friend writes about my results in the school newspaper: SECONDARY SOURCE
        A national newspaper writes about my friend's article: TERTIARY SOURCE
    

A mix of all types of sources are needed in most research projects, depending on the topic, audience, and purpose.Watch the following videos to learn more:



Reading:Types of Evidence Used to Write a Paper

mainContent.html:
3.3 Choosing Types of Evidence

Completion requirements

Evidence, the meat of the sandwich

So, if claims are the building blocks of all academic writing, and reasoning is the glue that keeps them together, then evidence is the actual building that takes shape. Evidence is the wooden structure that supports and is supported by all claims (building blocks). A better analogy might be that of the sandwich: claims are the bread (starters); reasoning are the condiments (the special sauce); and evidence is the main ingredient, the meat or the cheese, in the middle.  

Think of a paragraph as a sandwich. The C-E-C method illustrates this sandwich-making process:

C-E-C Paragraph:

      • Claim: topic sentence and reasoning (1-2 sentences)  
      • Evidence: quotes or data used as support (1-2 sentences) 
      • Commentary: analyzes the evidence and connects it to the claim. (2-4 sentences)

Evidence comes in all shapes and sizes. In English, teachers mainly require quotes from the text as evidence. In Social Studies, teachers may use artifacts (objects, maps, graphs). In science and math, data is primarily used as evidence. A mix of all evidence may be presented in longer research projects.

In humanities, evidence is measured on how close it is to the original source. An original source is also known as a primary source. If someone paraphrases a primary source, it becomes a secondary source. If someone paraphrases a secondary source, it becomes a tertiary source. And so on...

For example: 

  • I conduct an experiment on water quality and publish my results: PRIMARY SOURCE
  • My friend writes about my results in the school newspaper: SECONDARY SOURCE
  • A national newspaper writes about my friend's article: TERTIARY SOURCE

A mix of all types of sources are needed in most research projects, depending on the topic, audience, and purpose.

Watch the following videos to learn more:

Types of Evidence Used to Write a Paper
